512546.name: Chemo Port Seatbelt Pad
512546.gauge_description: 12 stitches and 9 rows = 4 inches in Hdc
512546.notes_html:
Designed for a dear friend with a chemo port in his chest. Often when he drives, the edge of the seatbelt will catch and tug on his chemo catheter, causing pain or sensitivity to the site & sometimes bleeding a little.

This seatbelt pad is wrapped around the upper portion of the seatbelt so the sharp edge won’t catch on the catheter.

Revised pattern:

Sizes Included in Pattern:
• 4½” x 4” (wrapped once around seatbelt)
• 4½” x 9¾” (wrapped almost twice around seatbelt)

See my other goodies here: http://www.ravelry.com/stores/dawni-criswell-designs

Please “like” my Facebook Crochet Page for sneak peeks of upcoming crochet patterns: https://www.facebook.com/DawniJeannDesigns

521956.gauge_pattern: Knitting gauge: 1 x 1 inch: 7 stitches and 8 rows.
521956.name: Mommy's Lifesaver Arm/Cast cozy
521956.sizes_available: size: length about 40 cm and 42 cm arm/cast circumreference.
521956.gauge_description: 7 stitches and 8 rows = 1 inch in Knitting gauge: 1 x 1 inch: 7 stitches and 8 rows.
521956.notes_html:
When I was in Bad Neustadt for the Sulcus Ulnaris Syndrome surgery (they moved my nerve - the second time) and cut up the whole ellbow,
my room neighbor had also an elbow surgery on her right arm. But her cast was taken off before she went home.
She has two little kids (2 and 4 years old). So she was afraid that they wouldn’t realize that she had troubles with her right arm and pull…
That was when she said a cast/arm cozy with skulls on it would keep them off….
So you can blame my hospital stay for this fun pattern.
I made it as a surprise gift to her :)

It’s very loose so it also fits as a cast cozy.
You can knit it tighter by leaving out pattern repeats and making the ribbing less wide.

You can use any 4- to 5-ply yarn (sock, Merino, Acrylic).

If she sends me her address I’m gonna send it to her…
It was the first thing I tried knitting after the second surgery. Took me longer than usual but there you are :)

Enjoy Mommy’s lifesaver cast cozy cover!

Als ich in Bad Neustadt zur Nervverlegung (Version 2.0) wegen dem Sulcus Ulnaris Syndrom war, hatte meine Bettnachbarin ebenfalls eine Ellbogen-OP. Im Gegensatz zu mir, wurde bei Ihr aber schon im Krankenhaus der Gips wieder abgenommen. Sie hatte dann Angst, dass ihre beiden kleinen Kinder (2 und 4 Jahre alt) versehentlich an ihrem lädierten Arm ziehen, weil ja kein Gips drum ist.
Dann meinte sie so ein Gips-/Armschoner mit Totenköpfen drauf würde bei ihre Kindern abschreckend wirken…

Und so wurde die Schnapsidee für diesen Gips-/Armschoner geboren.
Das erste Muster, das ich nach der 2.ten Nervverlegung gestrickt habe. Hat ewig gedauert.. aber das hab ich gebraucht :)
Und hier ist er.
Er paßt über ein Oberarmgipsschiene. Wenn er nur als Armschoner dienen soll, könnt Ihr den bund enger stricken und einige Rapporte am Arm weglassen.

Ihr könnt jedes 4- bis 5-fach Garn (Sockenwolle, Acrylgarn oder Merino) verwenden.

Ich will sie damit noch überraschen. Warte noch drauf, dass sie mir ihre Adresse schickt…

Viel Spaß beim Stricken von Mama’s Rettungs-Gipsschoner :)

users.about_me:
A passionate hobby knitter from Germany who loves to knit socks and colorful Fair Isle things...
I love Fair Isle and Alice Starmore designs. But also lace or lopi. Actually I had a good Aran and cable knitting time when I was about 15 - 17 and then started again in my mid-thirties when I discovered Lopi Pullovers. Later I turned to Fair Isle knitting. I'm fascinated by old techniques. I love colourful knitting and animals. I hope to contribute some more patterns in the future... So enjoy watching my projects and my first designs.


As people keep asking me whether they could use my charts:

Sure it’s okay to use them as long as you just use it for your family and friends and as long as you don’t sell the outcome or the pattern on a commercial basis.
If you sell them at the flea market because kids have grown out of them or at ebay, this is totally okay.

As you have put all your effort and material into it.

And you are certainly allowed to use the charts for charity projects.

However, as I sell the finished items myself (at the moment limited to Germany)
 - and only up to 2 - 4 items per month -
I would kindly ask you not become my competitor here.

Thanks for respecting this rule.

You can make pattern requests. If the mood fits and it works out I'm sure I will provide the pattern sooner or later.
So don't be shy.
But please understand that I cannot do any charts of comic/film/book characters because this would be a copyright/trademark infringement.
Any general pattern requests like hobbies, sports,animals, flowers, general items will be happily fullfilled.
Just mail/message me your pattern wish, including as detailed information as possible how the pattern shall look like.
E.g. a hat with trucks on it, sending a link to a picture of how the truck shall look like, color wishes and requested head size (I would be grateful if you also put in the head circumreference in cms not only in inches).

**However I would ask you not to use parts of my designs/charts or complete charts for your own commercial designs (so if you are yourself a designer).
My charts are artwork which is protected by copyright.**

**PLEASE NOTE:
My charts are copyright registered with the US copyright office and the DPMA.
This provides a legal basis for damages claims for copyright infringements. **

**Copyright infringements will not be tolerated.
If you poke the bear better be up to face the consequences!**

Also note: my free charts are NOT public domain. I'm still living so the copyright has not run out yet ... neither means free = public domain!
See [here][1] for yourself for the definition of public domain.
See also the definition of [German Urheberrecht][2].

If you make items for your family or friends from it you are welcome to also put the knitting instruction online (non-commercial).
I would then appreciate be named and referred to in your knitting instruction.

Thanks!


For designers: It's not that difficult to come up with a horse or dog chart of your own.
If you need help just send me a message and I try to help you making your own design.

Note: My patterns are intended for knitting in the round, They might not work knitted flat.
Usually my projects are knitted with 4-ply sock yarn of different manufacturers. 
Mainly Schoeller-Stahl, Buttinette sock yarn (e.g. Söckli) and Opal sock yarn.
You can also use 5-ply merino wool knit with 3.00 mm needles. Then the hats/cowls will turn out a little bit bigger but warmer and softer.

I knit holding the forecolour in the left hand (seen from myself) and the backcolour in the right hand. That is because I prefer the forecolor to be the dominant colour and "pop out" and the background colour to be less dominant.

Many people asked me what a tammy is. A tammy is a special kind of beret.
A peerie pattern is the small border pattern surrounding the main pattern. When you e.g. take a look at my dog patterns there's a paw peerie or bones peerie around them.

Most of my knitting instructions are at the moment only available in English.  The charts are both English and German.
If anybody is interested in a German knitting instruction, please let me know (just send me a message). Then I'll put it online as soon as possible.

Bei Interesse an einer deutschen Anleitung schreibt mir einfach eine Nachricht. Dann werde ich sie baldmöglichst bereitstellen.

Übrigens... da sich die testgestrickten Mützen und Schals inzwischen auf meinem Sofa stapeln und ich sie nicht alle aufsetzen kann (einen Teil habe ich inzwischen auch schon verschenkt), verkaufe ich die testgestrickten Mützen und Schals auch.
Allerdings derzeit nur in Deutschland und maximal 2 - 4 Strickstücke pro Monat.
Bei Interesse schickt mir einfach eine Nachricht.


I'm only human, so errors may occur.. ;-)
If you find errors in my knitting instructions or have questions just send me a message.
I will correct the pattern and send all downloaders an update as soon as possible.


I can't wait to see your projects.

My first ebook contains 6 of my first patterns:
![Just beanies][3]

My second ebook [Halloween fun knits][4] is available.
It contains 7 Halloween fun knit patterns:

* Halloween kitty baby hat
* Halloween kitty adult/bigger child beanie version
* Spider beanie
* Little pumpkin beanie
* Halloween ghost baby hat
* Halloween infinity scarf
* Tiny pirate or skull socks (baby socks)

![Halloween fun knits][5]

I would like to thank all Ravelrers who have given me pattern challenges so far.
For example the horse socks would not have come into existence without a pattern request.
Ravelry is really a source of inspiration. This is a thing of give and take. And no one-way street!
I'm looking forward to new challenges.

****Please Note!** Until recently Ravelry tolerated charts being added to the library. But as Ravelry has lately been flooded with copyrighted and trademarked charts it is not allowed anymore to add new ones.
So for pattern request I can only make complete patterns not charts anymore.**

****Please:** If you have used my charts already I would kindly ask you to attach your projects to it. Because otherwise they might be removed.
I don't know yet what will happen with my already published charts. They might be removed or moved to a different section.** 


News: erssie and me started the new group ["the knitting chartists"][6] giving you the chance to actively take part in our designing and charting process.
You can make pattern wishes there and take part in the chart lab.

Neuigkeiten:
erssie und ich wir haben eine neue Gruppe aufgemacht ["The knitting chartists"][7]. Ein kleines Wortspiel aus Chart und Artist (=Künstler)
Ihr könnt dort aktiv an unserer Musterentwicklung teilhaben und auch Eure Musterwünsche äußern.
Viel Spaß! 

New Charts on Craftsy!!!
As Ravelry does not allow new standalone charts to be added, you will find my new charts exclusively on Craftsy.
Just look for [stoperror][8] there.
I will add new free and for sale standalone charts there in the future.
So check them out :)

Neue Charts auf Craftsy!!!
Da bei Ravelry Einzelcharts nicht mehr erwünscht sind, sondern nur noch komplette Muster, hab ich angefangen neue Charts bei Craftsy einzustellen.
Es wird dort zukünftig auch wieder kostenlose neue Charts geben.
Also schaut mal dort vorbei! Es lohnt sich ganz bestimmt :)

Now SHE is doing T-shirts, too! :)
You can find me [here][9] at spreadshirt.com.

Jetzt macht Sie auch noch T-shirts :)
Ihr könnt mich auf Spreadshirt.de [hier][10] finden.

And there goes [ebook no 3][11]!
It contains 5 cute baby knits , 2 pairs of socks and 3 beanies.

![ebook no 3 Tiny knits baby knits][12]

Happy knitting!


I just uploaded my little [get well elbow song][13]...

In my Hospital gallows humor... I made [this little song][14]. ;-)


Text von Miserable day
 1. I stepped out of my bed and made my first mistake, cause the foot I stepped on wasn't yet awake... 

 Refrain:
 Miserable day.. o yeah, miserable day... it's been a miserable day today that's all I have to say. 
 Miserable day, that's all I have to say I wanna crawl into my bed and pull the blanket over my head. 

 2. I stepped into the kitchen, the coffee running through, the paper not unfolded so I got a black brown brew... 

 3. I stepped into the street and slipped on black ice.. I broke my elbow just before sunrise 

 4. Got out of the cast, my fingers going numb, my nerve was trapped, I want my elbow back! 

 5. My elbow nerve they couldn't fix cause my HB was 6.6 To be blamed for the laddie (latter) was a myoma , I called him Freddie. 

 6. At the hospital a male nurse jumped into the elevator. Oh you want to go to level 5, too?! I don't want - but I have to. 

 7. Freddie is gone, he weighed 2 kg. I'm slimmer than before, my clothes don't fit me anymore. A nurse mistook my hand for a Weisswurst. She sucked the blood out in little bites. Uugh! My hand was turning blue. 

 8. At the third surgery doctor tabbed a few times at my blue hand. Said two anxious eyes are looking at me. This was no anxiety. What my eyes did tell: Dr. stop it. It hurts like hell! 

 9. Doctor moved the nerve and told me the nerve will recover 1 mm a day. For 40 cm that's a damn long way! 

 10. My uncle said: You should sue the town for your fall. I said: Winter duty starts at 7 a.m. He said: You could have stayed down till then. 

 11. Deutsch. My Onkel hat gsacht verglach die Stadt, weil sie nicht gestreuet hat. Drauf ich Streupflicht is erst ab siebn. Drauf er, wärst halt so lang leng gebliebm. 




  [14]: http://www.sandra-jaeger.net/downloads/Miserable_day.WAV


  [1]: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public_domain
  [2]: http://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Urheberrecht
  [3]: http://images4.ravelrycache.com/uploads/stoperror/60508864/just_beanies_small.jpg
  [4]: http://www.ravelry.com/patterns/sources/halloween-fun-knits/patterns
  [5]: http://images4-b.ravelrycache.com/uploads/stoperror/191242817/cover_pic_Halloween_knits2_small_best_fit.jpg
  [6]: http://www.ravelry.com/groups/the-knitting-chartists
  [7]: http://www.ravelry.com/groups/the-knitting-chartists
  [8]: http://www.craftsy.com/user/929883
  [9]: http://www.spreadshirt.com/user/stoperror
  [10]: http://770582.spreadshirt.de/
  [11]: http://www.ravelry.com/patterns/sources/tiny-knits-fair-isle-baby-socks-and-baby-hats
  [12]: http://images4-b.ravelrycache.com/uploads/stoperror/193748157/baby_hats_and_socks_ebook1_small.jpg
  [13]: http://www.sandra-jaeger.net/downloads/ElbowSong.WAV

551389.name: Arm Cast Covers
551389.gauge_description: 4 stitches and 4 rows = 4 inches in 4 stitches 4" height = 12 stitches
551389.notes_html:
Universal cast covers can be used to give your broken arm a new style and protect your arm in the same process. These can be made in any color. They are great to have in the winter months when you want to play outside.

For giveaways, coupons and free patterns please visit my
Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/kryskrafts907
Pinterest: http://www.pinterest.com/kryskrafts907

Thanks for visiting!

** This pattern is Copyright created and designed by Krys’ Krafts. This pattern may not be distributed in any form, that includes pictures text and instructions. You are welcome to sell the items that you make using the pattern, but please put a link back to my shop.** Thanks.

552608.name: Key Ring Inhaler Cozy
552608.notes_html:
Tired of searching for your inhaler? This little cozy allows you to keep your inhaler always at the ready by attaching it to your key ring. At the same time, it keeps the inhaler clean and dry and secures the cap.

Albuterol inhalers come in a few different shapes. This pattern is for an inhaler shaped like the one pictured here but can be used for others that are close in size and shape. The dimensions of the inhaler pictured (not the cozy) are

toe to heel: 1.75” (4.5 cm.)
heel to cuff (to the very top): 2.75” (7 cm.) foot circumference: 3.75” (9.5 cm.)
leg circumference: 4” (10 cm.)

The yarn used in the sample was recycled yarn from a thrift-store sweater. Stash-diving encouraged!

This pattern incorporates my favorite heel, the Fish Lips Kiss Heel, which can be purchased separately for $1. Alternatively, other short-row heel techniques can be subbed:
Sweet Tomato Heel
No Wrap, No Gap Short-Row Heel
Japanese Short-Row Heel
German Short-Row Heel
Wrap and Turn Short Rows

Many thanks to NanaMamah and yarnmama797 for test knitting and to xsangel100 for testing and tech editing.
552608.notes:
Tired of searching for your inhaler? This little cozy allows you to keep your inhaler always at the ready by attaching it to your key ring. At the same time, it keeps the inhaler clean and dry and secures the cap.

Albuterol inhalers come in a few different shapes. This pattern is for an inhaler shaped like the one pictured here but can be used for others that are close in size and shape. The dimensions of the inhaler pictured (not the cozy) are

toe to heel: 1.75” (4.5 cm.)
heel to cuff (to the very top): 2.75” (7 cm.) foot circumference: 3.75” (9.5 cm.)
leg circumference: 4” (10 cm.)

The yarn used in the sample was recycled yarn from a thrift-store sweater. Stash-diving encouraged!

This pattern incorporates my favorite heel, the [Fish Lips Kiss Heel][1], which can be purchased separately for $1. Alternatively, other short-row heel techniques can be subbed:
[Sweet Tomato Heel][2]
[No Wrap, No Gap Short-Row Heel][3]
[Japanese Short-Row Heel][4]
[German Short-Row Heel][5]
[Wrap and Turn Short Rows][6]

Many thanks to NanaMamah and yarnmama797 for test knitting and to xsangel100 for testing and tech editing.

575862.name: Aerokat Asthma Inhaler Koozie
575862.notes_html:
My cat has feline asthma (yep, cats get asthma too) and as a result needs to use an inhaler. To give him the medicine he has to have a face mask pressed against his face and I noticed it was irritating his skin.

This pattern uses 100% cotton yarn so that it can be washed after every use and air dried. Pro-tip: Hobby Lobby’s I Love This Cotton in “bright green” matches the Aerokat perfectly!

There are two sizes available: Small or Large

Materials Needed:
US Size 4 needles
Small amount of 100% Cotton worsted weight yarn
Tapestry Needle

578265.name: Toe Sockies for Casts
578265.notes_html:
Toe only (no heel), tie-on half-sock for people stuck in leg casts with exposed toes. Basic pattern can be elaborated on with any stranded, texture or lacy eyelet design desired.

Sock is knit toe-up and finished with ribbing. Crocheted ties are added to keep the toe sock in place when being worn. Ties can also be done using I-Cord, braiding, or as sewn-on ribbons.

Because this half-sock takes so little yarn (less than a 100 yards), it’s a great use for oddball leftovers. Washable yarn recommended because the sockie will be exposed as the wearer walks around.

pattern_author.name: Kim Brody Salazar
pattern_author.notes:
I’ve been active in on-line knitting groups since the Internet first crawled from the primordial ARPANET sea. I ran wiseNeedle.com for 12+ years, offering up independent, non-sponsored, crowdsourced yarn reviews and knitting advice, but packed that in recently.

 I’ve dabbled in design, and have had some patterns published in KnitNet, and by Schaeffer Yarns and Classic Elite. But that put the deadline into my escape world, so now I release my stuff for free on [String-or-Nothing][1]. 

I also do a lot of research on historical embroidery, especially the counted styles of the early 1500s-late 1600s, and am the author of The New Carolingian Modelbook. I’m currently working on a sequel, and hope to publish it this year. String-or-Nothing documents lots of my stitching in addition to knitting.



  [1]: http://string-or-nothing.com

659567.name: Inhaler Gripper
659567.notes_html:
Inhaler snuggie/cozy. Standard size. Gauge is not important (instructions given for altering as necessary). I made it in sock yarn but i see no reason that with a few simple sums different yarns can’t be used. I hate seams so there aren’t any. I also hate weaving in so that only needs doing at the very end as per instructions. Please note this isn’t a traditional pattern and is more a guide on how to create the item in question; If you need help with this please feel free to PM me.

Materials: Scraps of yarn (45yds when working with sock yarn) and hook that gives firm material (I used a 2.75mm hook).

802428.name: Inhaler carrier
802428.gauge_description: 3 stitches and 2 rows = 1 inch in hdc, sc, chain, sl st
802428.notes_html:
Create that special inhaler carrier for someone who needs immediate use of their inhaler. You can also make variations of this. You may sell items you make from this pattern, but please reference me when publishing. Never misplace it again! This pattern has photo tutorials as well as a written pattern. Easy to follow , step by step pattern. Thank you for your purchase.

Made for the ventolin asthma inhalers but it is stretchy. It may fit many kinds but not guaranteed

805216.name: Crocheted Cast Sock
805216.notes_html:
This pattern contains instructions for both a small (Child) and a large (Teen/Adult) toe/cast cover using either Medium Worsted Weight Yarn such as Bernat Super Value or a light Worsted weight yarn such as Caron Simply Soft.

Pattern Difficulty: Beginner/Intermediate

Written both US and metric measurements.

This Pattern is designed so the sock will not slip off the cast.

It also has instructions for color changing at the cuff.

A great project to use up some leftover yarn.

Pattern Difficulty: Beginner/Intermediate

Written both US and metric measurements.

Ahhh the dreaded plaster cast. With the reduced blood flow and activity following surgery or an injury the discomfort maybe exaggerated. There’s nothing worse than cold toes. This cozy will help keep your toes warm and hidden.

Copyright©2017

pattern_author.name: Terrilene Luxon
pattern_author.notes:
My username is Terrilene and my website is https://www.terrilenescraftroom.com/
Mom to one awesome daughter and "Gramma" to two sweet little girls. My mother taught me how to crochet, knit and sew at a young age and I love all of it. Now retired,, I was a Maintenance Manager at our local Nuclear Generating Station for 30 years. When trying to plan for my retirement, I decided to set up this shop and with a little luck, it grows enough to keep me busy in my retirement years. :)
Some of the profit from this shop goes towards purchasing craft tools, material and yarn to make charitable items. I especially enjoy making blankets, hats, mitts, scarves and preemie clothes for charities.

My username is Terrilene and my website is https://www.terrilenescraftroom.com/
Mom to one awesome daughter and "Gramma" to two sweet little girls. My mother taught me how to crochet, knit and sew at a young age and I love all of it. Now retired,, I was a Maintenance Manager at our local Nuclear Generating Station for 30 years. When trying to plan for my retirement, I decided to set up this shop and with a little luck, it grows enough to keep me busy in my retirement years. :)
Some of the profit from this shop goes towards purchasing craft tools, material and yarn to make charitable items. I especially enjoy making blankets, hats, mitts, scarves and preemie clothes for charities.

839065.name: Dialysis Catheter Sleeve
839065.notes_html:
If you have a loved one that goes to dialysis three times a week, they may find comfort if a loved one crochets a dialysis catheter cover for them. I know my grandfather did. Unfortunately he has passed, but he’s the reason this pattern exists today. I discontinued it after his passing, but after multiple requests, I have decided to bring it back.

Crochet pattern designed by Summerbug Crafts. Feel free to sell dialysis catheter covers made using this crochet pattern, but give credit to @summerbugcrafts!

users.about_me:
Hi, I'm Summer! I'm an amigurumi designer from Toronto (originally Campbellford). My Ravelry shop was once known as SummerBugCrafts. After taking a break from crochet & designing, I have decided to reintroduce my crochet/amigurumi patterns to the world again. 

If you remember me back when I was originally designing and selling my crochet patterns (2015-2018), they were mostly for crochet accessories and a few amigurumi in the mix. Now I have discovered my true love is designing amigurumi plushies to crochet, so that will be my main focus here, especially video game characters and other geeky icons!

So, without further ado... let's crochet, nerds!

846717.name: Toezees -- Toe Warmers
846717.notes_html:
Description: Seamless toe warmers with sufficient air circulation; extend up to arches; ideal for individuals who wear toeless walking boots/foot casts and elderly who are non-ambulatory and suffer from diabetes, edema/swollen feet and legs, poor circulation and other foot issues

Materials Needed: About 120 yards of worsted weight yarn
Size H Hook for medium and large size Toezees
Size I Hook for chaining
Size of Toezees: Medium – width around is 10 “, length from top of ribbing toe to end of Toezee is 7 ½”.
Large – width around is 11”, length from top of ribbing to end of Toezee is 8 ½”.
Note: Due to varying thickness of worsted weight brands of yarn, size of Toezees may be slightly larger or smaller than what is stated above.
To lengthen or shorten Toezee, do more or fewer rounds as stated in Round 8 in pattern.
To make Toezee wider, go up a hook size. To make the Toezee narrower, go down a hook size

Made in all one color.

893970.name: Seatbelt Cozy
893970.gauge_description: 16 stitches and 22 rows = 4 inches in Stockinette stitch
893970.notes_html:
This seatbelt cozy wraps around the portion of a car seatbelt that crosses over the chest to provide a bit of cushioning. This design was created as a special request by an oncology nurse for patients who have chemo ports implanted in their chests.

This project is worked flat and when folded over the seatbelt it is secured with bobble buttons that are knit as part of the pattern.

Finished item measures 6 in x 9 1/2 in when flat, and just about 2 1/2 in wide when folded and buttoned.

898375.name: Lanyard and Pouch for Glucose Monitor
898375.notes_html:
This is a simple crocheted pouch in a size intended to fit the Freestyle Libre glucose monitor or other devices of comparable size (about 4 inches tall by 2.25 inches wide by 0.5 inches deep). The pouch has a button closure at the top to keep your monitor secure. Having the pouch attached to a lanyard makes it possible to wear your monitor at all times (I mostly wear mine this way while I’m sleeping) and have it within easy reach when you need it.

Pouch is worked in crochet; lanyard i-cord is knitted. You can opt to work the i-cord in crochet, if you prefer, or use some other method to make the lanyard. You may also make the lanyard longer or shorter, depending on what’s most comfortable to you.

This pouch-on-a-lanyard can also be a fun item for children (only ones who are old enough to safely wear a lanyard around their neck!!) to gather small treasures during nature hikes or shells and stones while walking on the beach, etc. -- just make the lanyard a shorter length to fit your child.

This pouch can also be a convenient, comfortable way to carry a pocket-size hand sanitizer with your everywhere you go.

Pattern can be completed in a couple of hours and uses only a small amount of worsted weight yarn, about 35 yards; cotton worsted weight yarn suggested.

I also enjoy designing and sharing patterns, projects, links, and ideas for yarncrafters. (For my day job, editing English is my super power. @editorsusan)

And, in case you're wondering, I am Raveler No. 1100186! :-)

users.about_me_html:
At Yarncraft by Susan, knitting, crochet and other fibercrafts are a passion. I like designs that incorporate form with function, and beauty with utility and comfort, and I am particularly intrigued by apparel designs that are constructed using unconventional methods. I also enjoy designing and sharing patterns, projects, links, and ideas for yarncrafters. (For my day job, editing English is my super power. @editorsusan)

#bistitchual

Fibercrafting is my method of daily meditation. It’s how I relax and unwind every evening. The rhythm, repetition and counting to create a motif of stitches are my calming mantra. This work uplifts my mind, eases my spirit, and keeps me centered.

And, in case you’re wondering, I am Raveler No. 1100186! :-)

I prefer the incantation “confervo,” personally, but …

Spell Name: The Knitting Charm

Incantation: Knacocio (nah-co-CI-O)

Wand Movement: Starting from the top right hand corner, draw a V, ending at the top left corner, then making a U shape curve back to the top right hand corner. (Incantation said after the wand movement)

Focus Component: The caster must focus closely on the knitting needles and how each stitch is made. As there are different types of stitches, the caster needs to constantly focus on the type of stitching they would like to use during the knitting. The caster needs to visualise the knitting design in their mind, and if they were to lose focus, they will end up having a messy ball of yarn.

Will Power Component: The spell requires minimal will power as there is no backfiring effect if the spell is cast wrongly. The caster will merely have a problem unstitching the yarn. More willpower will be needed if the design is complex and constantly changing. Also, varying willpower is needed when knitting different types of products. For example, knitting a scarf would definitely need less willpower than knitting a sweater.

Concentration Component: Knitting requires two knitting needles and thus it will be a challenge to split the concentration into two parts that are actively happening concurrently.

Summary/Description: This spell is a necessary spell as it is used for common activities. The spell cast may seem like an easy task; however, there is still some minimal complexity in terms of concentration when it comes to controlling both needles at the same time. When spell is successfully cast, the caster would be able to knit things such as scarves, jumpers, mittens, hats etc.
